docs.text: Welcome # Here I've started to gather my knowledge on all things Cyber. Tools and techniques used by both analysts and threat actors which I've found useful to record. About # The information on this blog is for educational purposes only. Opinions expressed are solely my own and do not express the views or opinions of my employer.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Here I've started to gather my knowledge on all things Cyber. Tools and techniques used by both analysts and threat actors which I've found useful to record.
docs.title: Welcome

docs.text: The information on this blog is for educational purposes only. Opinions expressed are solely my own and do not express the views or opinions of my employer.
docs.title: About

docs.text: APT Package Manager # Update list of packages (check for new versions) # sudo apt-get update Upgrade installed packages # sudo apt upgrade Perform major updates # sudo apt full-upgrade Remove unneeded or unused packages (in order to save disk space) # sudo apt --purge autoremove
docs.title: APT Package Manager

docs.text: sudo apt-get update
docs.title: Update list of packages (check for new versions)

docs.text: sudo apt upgrade
docs.title: Upgrade installed packages

docs.text: sudo apt full-upgrade
docs.title: Perform major updates

docs.text: sudo apt --purge autoremove
docs.title: Remove unneeded or unused packages (in order to save disk space)

docs.text: Common AWS commands # Login using saved credentials # eval $(aws ecr get-login --no-include-email | sed 's|https://||')
docs.title: AWS

docs.text: eval $(aws ecr get-login --no-include-email | sed 's|https://||')
docs.title: Login using saved credentials

docs.text: Useful Bash commands # Find text in files easily # grep * string Find a file containing specific text # grep -rnw '/path/to/somewhere/' -e 'pattern' Identify the Linux distribution # cat /proc/version lsb_release -a ID the RAM # sudo dmidecode --type 17 Set Timezone # sudo timedatectl set-timezone Australia/Sydney
docs.title: Bash

docs.text: grep * string
docs.title: Find text in files easily

docs.text: grep -rnw '/path/to/somewhere/' -e 'pattern'
docs.title: Find a file containing specific text

docs.text: cat /proc/version lsb_release -a
docs.title: Identify the Linux distribution

docs.text: sudo dmidecode --type 17
docs.title: ID the RAM

docs.text: sudo timedatectl set-timezone Australia/Sydney
docs.title: Set Timezone

docs.text: Customization # For details about standard mkdocs options, see MkDocs Configuration . Extra configuration options # In addition, the Windmill Dark theme supports a few additional options, which may be listed under the extra: key of mkdocs.yml . extra.logo : Path to a logo to include in the top bar next to the site name. extra.version : Version number to include right under the site name. and under in mkdocs_theme.yml . article_nav_top : Set to false to hide the Previous/Next navigation buttons above article contents. article_nav_bottom : Set to false to hide the Previous/Next navigation buttons below article contents. history_buttons : Include back/forward buttons in the top bar. This is useful when the documentation site is included into a bare browser, e.g. into an Electron-based application.
docs.title: Customization

docs.text: For details about standard mkdocs options, see MkDocs Configuration .
docs.title: Customization

docs.text: In addition, the Windmill Dark theme supports a few additional options, which may be listed under the extra: key of mkdocs.yml . extra.logo : Path to a logo to include in the top bar next to the site name. extra.version : Version number to include right under the site name. and under in mkdocs_theme.yml . article_nav_top : Set to false to hide the Previous/Next navigation buttons above article contents. article_nav_bottom : Set to false to hide the Previous/Next navigation buttons below article contents. history_buttons : Include back/forward buttons in the top bar. This is useful when the documentation site is included into a bare browser, e.g. into an Electron-based application.
docs.title: Extra configuration options

docs.text: Useful Docker Commands # List all running containers # docker ps List all running and stopped containers # docker ps -a Build and tag an image ready for storage in ECR # docker build -t appname:1.2.4 ./misp --tag 000000000000.dkr.ecr.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/appname:1.2.4 note: replace 000000000000 with AWS account number and change region if required Push image to ECR # docker push 000000000000.dkr.ecr.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/appname:1.2.4 Terminate and re-deploy Elastic Beanstalk application using saved config # eb terminate --force && eb create appname -cfg appname Clear all saved images and containers locally # docker rm -f $(docker ps -a -q) docker rmi -f $(docker images -q) Check it worked # docker ps -a docker images
docs.title: Docker

docs.text: docker ps
docs.title: List all running containers

docs.text: docker ps -a
docs.title: List all running and stopped containers

docs.text: docker build -t appname:1.2.4 ./misp --tag 000000000000.dkr.ecr.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/appname:1.2.4 note: replace 000000000000 with AWS account number and change region if required
docs.title: Build and tag an image ready for storage in ECR

docs.text: docker push 000000000000.dkr.ecr.ap-southeast-2.amazonaws.com/appname:1.2.4
docs.title: Push image to ECR

docs.text: eb terminate --force && eb create appname -cfg appname
docs.title: Terminate and re-deploy Elastic Beanstalk application using saved config

docs.text: docker rm -f $(docker ps -a -q) docker rmi -f $(docker images -q)
docs.title: Clear all saved images and containers locally

docs.text: docker ps -a docker images
docs.title: Check it worked

docs.text: Pacman Package Manager # Update all packages # sudo pacman -Syu Update specific package # sudo pacman -Syu <package-name> Search for package # sudo pacman -Ss <keyword>
docs.title: Pacman Package Manager

docs.text: sudo pacman -Syu
docs.title: Update all packages

docs.text: sudo pacman -Syu <package-name>
docs.title: Update specific package

docs.text: sudo pacman -Ss <keyword>
docs.title: Search for package

docs.text: Useful PowerShell commands #
docs.title: Useful PowerShell commands

docs.text: Python # Variables # variablename = 10 Declare and set value type(variablename) Output type (string, float, list, integer, boolean) Write output # print "string" print (variablename) print "string" + str(variablename) + "another string" Mathematical operations # 1 + 2 1 / 2 1 * 2 1 - 2 Standard algebra 5 % 3 Modulo: gives the remainder of 5 divided by 3 (2) 4 ** 3 Four to the power of 3 (64) Indexing and slicing # indexname = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] Build and populate index print(indexname[1:2]) Output second and third index values ( b, c ) print(indexname[2:]) Output third to final index values ( c, d ) print(indexname[:1]) Output first to second values ( a, b) Other info # Lists can contain other lists
docs.title: Python

docs.text: variablename = 10 Declare and set value type(variablename) Output type (string, float, list, integer, boolean)
docs.title: Variables

docs.text: print "string" print (variablename) print "string" + str(variablename) + "another string"
docs.title: Write output

docs.text: 1 + 2 1 / 2 1 * 2 1 - 2 Standard algebra 5 % 3 Modulo: gives the remainder of 5 divided by 3 (2) 4 ** 3 Four to the power of 3 (64)
docs.title: Mathematical operations

docs.text: indexname = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd'] Build and populate index print(indexname[1:2]) Output second and third index values ( b, c ) print(indexname[2:]) Output third to final index values ( c, d ) print(indexname[:1]) Output first to second values ( a, b)
docs.title: Indexing and slicing

docs.text: Lists can contain other lists
docs.title: Other info

docs.text: Splunk # Commands # dedup Removes duplicates Stats functions # count sum avg Chart commands # | chart count over rowfieldname_name by columnfieldname over (x) (can be named) by (y) (numeric) Usenull & Useother # usenull=f removes the NULL values from a chart but better to imply blah=* to remove blanks earlier useother=f removes the OTHER values from a chart limit=10 is default/max limit=0 is all Clustering chart timelines # span=12h clusters the normal 24hr to 12hr timewrap=7d makes weekly series Other Gotchas # field names are case sensitive, values are not field values from a Lookup are case sensitive boolean are UPPER (AND OR)
docs.title: Splunk
